DeVries the widow was the plaintiff in lower court and is the respondants on Supreme Court. The manufacturers were the defendants in lower court and are the petitioner in Supreme Court. District court ruled in favor of the manufacturers on both counts of strict liability and negligence. The widow appealed. The Appellate court remanded on the negligence, asking the district court to clarify their decision: was it a bright line rule (meaning in no case a manufacturer would be liable for other parts of a product that were made by someone else, or added on later), or was it case-specific. The district court said it was a bright line ruling. The circuit (appellate) court said the district court was wrong: the manufacturers could have warned about the harmful component (asbestos) in its operating and maintenance manuals. They knew about the danger, and they knew that asbestos would have to be used even though when they shipped the product (in parts to be assembled), asbestos was not present.

From the Oyez source above, I'm going with the "bright-line" defense that the SCOTUS prefers.  It also prefers to not apply laws outside of the main purview of the U.S. justice system, in this case maritime law, and the appellate court  in this case ruled a "strict-line", subjective verdict according to maritime law.
Can products-liability defendants, especially corporations, be held liable under maritime law for injuries caused by products that they did not make, sell, or distribute?
The only question the Court will actually consider in this case is, "Is Air and Liquid Etcetera a company?"  If the answer is Yes, the company will prevail.
